0156027321|4.0|The novel is excellent in terms of its thematics: on belief, on a human's place in the ecosystem, and so on. Its images are powerful, both those that are beautiful and those that are horrifying. There's a good bit of violence described in the novel, a good bit of blood and guts and all that would or might attend a story about surviving at sea with (possibly) four wild animals or (possibly) other desperate humans. Not for the squeamish. Not for those who can't stop anthropomorphizing animals or who won't bear the savagery born of desperation to live. It's not a question of narrative skill on Martel's part, but of the reader's taste or capacity to handle these scenes. One might then ask, is there any comparison between enduring reading about these incidents and actually enduring them? Hardly, but I found the reading of such to be so gruelling that I docked the novel a star.

The plot centers around James Herriot, a newly qualified veternarian and his employment as assistant veternarian to Siegfried Farnon in the village of Darrowby. You will also meet a cast of colorful characters, Tristian Farnon, Siegfried's younger brother, Helen Alderson, Mrs. Hall, Mrs. Pumphrey and her Pekinese, Tricky-Woo,and a host of other colorful characters who make this a memorable read. James Herriot has also authored several other books, each one stands on its own merit and are a treasure for your family library. The BBC also produced the series \\" All Creatures Great and Small\\" for television in the late 1970's. The series is a masterpiece! I would highly recommend watching the episodes as you read through the books. The books/series are fantastic family entertainment!

B00008WJBU|2.0|\\"Intacto\\" concerns a hidden subculture of people who can steal luck from others, and barter or win it from each other.  An intriguing concept, to be sure, and it makes for a good premise for a film.<br /><br />A movie needs more than a high concept, though.  A fantasy like this demands a lot in its execution.  In particular, the script must establish an internal logic very early on, and follow that internal logic, in order to allow the audience to suspend their disbelief and enter into the fantasy.  \\"Intacto\\" unfortunately throws internal logic and common sense right out the window.  The characters' actions make no sense much of the time, and the script and direction obfuscate and confuse rather than advance any kind of plot.  Contrast this with the superior movie \\"The Cooler,\\" which also dealt with a man who could affect the luck of others.  Whatever its faults, and it had some, at least the basic premise of the cooler's relationship with luck & how it worked was set out early in the movie, and was comprehensible.<br /><br />I'll give it an extra star for trying something different, and for generally good performances.  But, I wouldn't watch this again.  If you're at the video store at 11 pm on Friday and your only choices are this, \\"Shattered Glass\\" and some WWF videos, just go home and read a book.

And the modern vampire world created by Ms. Sparks is so cleverly creative.<br /><br />The handsome Roman is a fabulous wounded hero, vulnerable in spite of his unnatural abilities, and Shanna, the heroine, is smart and funny -- a worthy match for him.  I can't wait for the next one.  Bring on the vamps!

B0006399FS|4.0|I'm astonished at the number of negative reviews that U2' s \\"How to Dismantle an Atomic Bomb\\" has gotten on Amazon.  To be sure, this is far from U2's best album; they may never top 1987's \\"The Joshua Tree.\\"  And it's not as immediately appealing as their 2000 comeback, \\"All That You Can't Leave Behind.\\"  But to my ears, this is a solid and rewarding rock album, without frills or gimmickry. <br /> <br />U2 isn't going for an experimental sound, as they did with \\"Achtung Baby\\" or \\"Zooropa,\\" nor are they trying to integrate past successes as they did on \\"All That You Can't Leave Behind.\\"  Rather, they crystallize their sound to deliver a personal, introspective set of songs, driven as much by the three instrumentalists as by Bono's reliably passionate lyrics and vocals. Adam Clayton's booming bass powers songs like \\"Love and Peace or Else\\" and \\"A Man and a Woman.\\"  The Edge continues to find nuances for his signature sound, experimenting with feedback and distortion.  Larry Mullen Jr., one of rock's least flashy drummers, is solid and reliable as ever.  For his part, Bono employs octave harmonies to create a haunting, hypnotic effect on tracks like \\"Crumbs from your Table,\\" \\"All Because of You,\\" and \\"Yahweh\\".  <br /> <br />The unconventional track sequencing may disorient the casual listener.  For example, U2 breaks the momentum established by the energetic opener, \\"Vertigo,\\" with a couple of mid-tempo tracks, \\"Miracle Drug\\" and \\"Sometime You Can't Make it On Your Own.\\" These songs build slowly and require repeated listening to appreciate. <br /> <br />While \\"How to Dismantle an Atomic Bomb\\" doesn't achieve the lofty heights of \\"All That You Can't Leave Behind\\" - there's nothing quite as impressive as \\"Beautiful Day,\\" \\"Walk On,\\" or \\"Kite\\" - it's more consistent throughout. The weakest songs occur toward album's end: the moody \\"One Step Closer\\" never fully develops, and \\"Original of the Species\\" sounds like it was cobbled from bits of earlier U2 songs.   <br /> <br />With \\"How to Dismantle an Atomic Bomb,\\" U2 succeeds in honing their sound into a mature, cohesive work.  It's a noble and worthy addition to the discography of one of rock's all-time great bands.

B000002J0B|5.0|Houses of The Holy(1973). Led Zeppelin's Fifth Album.<br /><br />By the time 'Houses of The Holy' was released, Led Zeppelin was a rock phenomenon. 'Zoso(IV)' and 'Led Zeppelin II' had both sold over ten million copies, and Led Zeppelin was accepted with a frenzy that hadn't been seen since the Beatles and Elvis. When released, 'Houses of the Holy' shot to the top of the charts, and songs like 'Over The Hills And Far Away', 'Dancing Days', 'D'Yer Mak'er' , and 'The Ocean' became massive hits for Led Zeppelin. This album went on to sell over ten million copies, and is one of Led Zeppelin's most recognized and praised albums. So is this album as good as you'd expect? Read on to find out!<br /><br />Track Rating-<br /><br />The Song Remains The Same- Jimmy Page's little guitar opera, \\"The Song Remains The Same\\" blares out of your speakers, sonically drenching you with Page's blasting power chords and John Paul Jones funky bassline. This song is totally original, as you won't really hear anything like it. A little bluesy, funky, and progressive, it's a mishmash of rock styles, and it plays out perfectly. Page is amazing here! You can actually feel the emotion here! Amazing epic little song.<br /><br />The Rain Song- Although not a mainstream song, \\"The Rain Song\\" has remained a fan favorite over the years. A sad little folk tune, Jimmy Page's soft, brooding guitar melodies are truly beautiful. Robert Plant's vocals are very hushed and thoughtful, and really fit the song. Although some may overlook this one, listen to this in a quiet place, and you'll see it's beauty.<br /><br />Over The Hills And Far Away- A huge hit for Led Zeppelin, \\"Over The Hills And Far Away\\" is a blend of folk and hard rock, and remains fresh to his day. Page's and Plant's soft melodies soon burst into a loud, boisterous, hard rocker that Zeppelin does best. Crank the volume up, sit back, and listen to some good classic rock.<br /><br />The Crunge- \\"The Crunge\\" is an unabashed funk song, and it's absolutely amazing. Freaky cool drumming, a super-funky bassline, and funky guitar licks that you might think come from Prince. Although I might be making it sound like this sounds like a totally different band, this is still obviously Led Zeppelin. Funky and awesome.<br /><br />Dancing Days- A rather dark song, \\"Dancing Days\\" celestial power chords blow out your speakers in dramatic fashion, not unlike the masterful \\"Kashmir\\". Plant's vocals are dark and mysterious, and Page's brilliant guitarwork awes me everyday. How do you not like it?<br /><br />D'Yer Mak'er- \\"D'Yer Mak'er\\" finds Led Zeppelin playing back to their reggae influences, and the results are amazing. A lot like \\"All of My Love\\", \\"D'Yer Mak'er\\" is much heavier, but they both are emotional love songs. Gotta love this one.<br /><br />No Quarter- For a while, \\"No Quarter\\" was my favorite Led Zeppelin track. Although not anymore, when I first listened to this masterpiece, I was overcome by it. Very weird and experimental, \\"No Quarter\\" is very slow-paced and melodic, but the spooky verses lead up to an amazing chorus. Jimmy Page's ultra-distorted riffs are extremely cool, and were the reason I became so hooked. Plant's vocals are very celestial... it's almost as if hearing a ghost whisper to you from the afterlife. John Paul Jones and Page both play beautiful piano and guitar harmonies, and they sound fantastic. Not for everyone, but if you give it a chance, I'm sure you'll love it.<br /><br />The Ocean- Another favorite of mine, \\"The Ocean\\" is pure, classic hard rock. It oozes sarcasm and bad behavior, and truly has a pure rock sound. Page's loud, addictive power chords back Plant's loud, sarcastic vocals. This song is totally addictive... put this song on at a party, it should get people dancing(unless they listen to rap!). Awesome.<br /><br />'Houses of the Holy' is an amazing album. It's hard to say, but it might just be my favorite. With a combination of blazing hard rock like \\"The Ocean\\" and \\"Over The Hills and Far Away\\", not to mention epics like \\"The Rain Song\\", \\"No Quarter\\", and the \\"The Song Remains The Same\\", this album seems to cover all of Zeppelin's different styles into a tight package. It seems like Led Zeppelin has the Midas touch... everything they touch turns to gold. If you have a classic rock collection without this album, it's not complete. Please buy this album.<br /><br />Also Recommended-<br /><br />Led Zeppelin II- Led Zeppelin<br /><br />Toys In The Attic- Aerosmith<br /><br />Billion Dollar Babies- Alice Cooper<br /><br />Thanks For Reading!\\"The Ocean\\" and \\"Over The Hills and Far Away\\", not to mention epics like \\"The Rain Song\\", \\"No Quarter\\", and the \\"The Song Remains The Same\\", this album seems to cover all of Zeppelin's different styles into a tight package. It seems like Led Zeppelin has the Midas touch... everything they touch turns to gold. If you have a classic rock collection without this album, it's not complete. Please buy this album.  <br /> <br />Also Recommended-  <br /> <br />Led Zeppelin II- Led Zeppelin <br />Toys In The Attic- Aerosmith <br />Billion Dollar Babies- Alice Cooper <br /> <br />Thanks For Reading! <br /> <br />

B00004Y6O9|5.0|Van Halen(1978). Van Halen's First Record.<br /><br />Around 1975, after immigrating to America, brothers Eddie Van Halen and Alex Van Halen teamed up with bassist Michael Anthony and vocalist David Lee Roth to form Mammoth. After later changing their name to Van Halen, the band was noticed by KISS vocalist Gene Simmons, and he immediately got them a record deal. In 1978, Van Halen was released with much fanfare, pushing the singles \\"Runnin' With The Devil\\", \\"Ain't Talkin' Bout Love\\", and \\"Jamies' Cryin\\". Later, guitarists' favorite, \\"Eruption\\", and the singles \\"You Really Got Me\\" and \\"Ice Cream Man\\" became huge hits. Because of it's upbeat mood and hip new sound, 'Van Halen' became a popular party album, and sold over 10 million copies. Without a doubt, Van Halen was destined to be rock superstars, but is this album just overrated? Read on to find out!<br /><br /> In 1978, Van Halen was the newest sound on the block. Eddie Van Halen's guitar techniques were unheard of! Things like 'tapping' and 'divebombs' were unheard of in the 70's, although they later were abused to death by hair metal bands. His style and tone were completely new, and this album manages to hold up even after all these years. David Lee Roth, although he wasn't the best vocalist, his vocals seemed to fit perfectly, and he was the perfect rock singer: showy and over-the-top. Alex Van Halen has always been a favorite drummer of mine, and songs like \\"Jamies' Cryin'\\" and \\"Eruption\\" he performs flawlessly. Micheal Anthony is an awesome bassist, and the work on this album and later Van Halen albums is amazing.<br /><br /> As you can tell, Van Halen was full of great musicians, but they were also amazing songwriters. \\"Jamies' Cryin\\" and \\"Little Dreamer\\" are both poignant love songs, and they stand out as some of their best. \\"Ain't Talkin' Bout Love\\", \\"I'm The One\\", \\"Feel Your Love Tonight\\", and \\"On Fire\\" are all badass rock n' rollers, songs that Van Halen are best known for.  If you like these songs, you will love Van Halen. \\"Runnin' With The Devil\\" is an interesting song, a song that will take many back to their days as a rebel. \\"You Really Got Me\\" is a cover of a Kinks classic, and Van Halen serves proper justice to this classic. This is one of the coolest songs on the album... that riff just sucks you in! \\"Atomic Punk\\" and \\"Ice Cream Man\\" are both funky tunes that any fan will recognize... they both show Van Halen had a sense of humor. Of course, there's \\"Eruption\\" the fabled guitar tune that spawned a generation of wankers and finger tapping guitarists who idolized Eddie Van Halen. To this day, it's still amazing.<br /><br /> What can I say? This album is flawless. Every song is amazing, and this album is well-worth the low price. Along with '1984', this album is absolutely essential for Van Halen fans.  It's amazing, you can still play this album at parties! If you're a fan of rock and metal, I pity you if you don't own this album... your collection is lacking! This is one of those albums you can listen to a million times and never get tired of.<br /><br />(...)\\"Runnin' With The Devil\\" is an interesting song, a song that will take many back to their days as a rebel. \\"You Really Got Me\\" is a cover of a Kinks classic, and Van Halen serves proper justice to this classic. This is one of the coolest songs on the album... that riff just sucks you in! \\"Atomic Punk\\" and \\"Ice Cream Man\\" are both funky tunes that any fan will recognize... they both show Van Halen had a sense of humor. Of course, there's \\"Eruption\\" the fabled guitar tune that spawned a generation of wankers and finger tapping guitarists who idolized Eddie Van Halen. To this day, it's still amazing.     What can I say? This album is flawless. Every song is amazing, and this album is well-worth the low price. Along with '1984', this album is absolutely essential for Van Halen fans.  It's amazing, you can still play this album at parties! If you're a fan of rock and metal, I pity you if you don't own this album... your collection is lacking! This is one of those albums you can listen to a million times and never get tired of.     (...)
B00025ETIW|3.0|My Chemical Romance is a band that tends to stand out from the rest of the MTV rock band crowd, a band that seems to make a musical statement rather than a financial one.<br /><br />By that I mean, MCR is more talented than most emo that I have heard. I commend them, because they are the only emo band that has actually influenced me to purchase one of their CDs. I don't own a single other emo CD in my entire collection (500+ discs). Amazingly, MCR's \\"Three Cheers for Sweet Revenge\\" STILL gets heavy rotation in my CD Player.<br /><br />This album has many promising tracks, such as Helena, To The End, I'm Not Okay, The Ghost of You (which actually influenced me to buy the album), The Jetset Life Is Going to Kill You, and Cemetery Drive.<br /><br />I'll admit I was disappointed however, because I was not expecting emo the day I bought the album. \\"The Ghost of You\\" denies any existence of emo within reachable distance of the band, so I was expecting something along the lines of Modest Mouse, Muse, Radiohead, etc. Upon hearing \\"Helena\\" as the first track, I said, 'Wow...this sounds a lot like emo. I really don't like this.'<br /><br />But as time went on, I learned to appreciate it for what it was, and though I'm not an emo fan, I still do listen to this album quite often.<br /><br />The only problem I have with this album is the production. I know most people couldn't care about how modern music is mastered to blow out their ears within five listens, but I care about my hearing (being an audio engineer). I believe this album would have been much better if the energy hadn't been raped by smashing the dynamics to complete dust. Songs like \\"To The End\\" constantly push the 0 mark on the dB meter during the verse, and has no room to build up or get louder when the chorus kicks in. It makes the song uninteresting and less engergetic, even if the song was performed with great energy and skill (as most of them are on this disc).<br /><br />I set a higher standard for MCR than most emo bands, but they still are at a lower level of respect to me than most bands I listen to. My Chemical Romance is still JUST a band to me; maybe some day when they decide to be more artistic and show a view other than death, I will come to appreciate them more.<br /><br />I know most of the viewers here could care less to what I have to say about the band or the album in general, just that \\"I'm Not Okay\\" hazz to bee the bezt song in existEnCe!!! Joel Schumacher and Andrew Lloyd Webber did a wonderful job in transforming this drawing production into a film that will be treasured for years to come. B000819PKC|4.0|It was a long wait between albums, but at least it was worth it.  If you're a big fan of their first two albums, which are a lot less produced and have more of a raw edge to them, then this isn't going to be up your alley.  If you're more of a fan of their past few albums, then you'll probably be more into this.  I enjoy both types of their music, but it would be nice if just once we could hear a didgeridoo again on an album.  Although I know in different interviews Jay Kay has said that every song can't have social impact, that sometimes you just have to write songs to dance to, it would also be nice if there was a little more connection to the Earth.  If you're going to incorporate a North American Indian tribe into your group's name, then you can't ignore those kind of connections.<br />That being said, there is some great work on the album and more than enough beats to get you moving.  The only track that seems to fail is &quot;Love is Blind&quot;, which eventually grows on you, but will initially sound like a mess. When that track goes into the bridge, you'll be wondering why they didn't do the whole song like that.<br />Even though the band has lost a couple of members (to things like wanting to spend more time with kids), you won't notice a big difference in the musicianship.  Since there is a lot more production here than on the first two albums, the beats and bass work are simple enough that any skilled musician should be able to handle things.  Jay Kay's voice is still dead on and hasn't changed at all over the years.  <br />Highlights from the album have to the title track, &quot;Dynamite&quot;, where the backing vocals are used effectively (you'll find yourself chanting &quot;Dynamite, dynamite&quot; while you're driving) and &quot;Talullah&quot;, where Jay Kay shows that he can still make a slower jam have a little bite, allowing the bassline to do the work.<br />So yeah, a great album, but a little overproduced if you like their earlier stuff.  Get ready to move.
B000002U82|4.0|Obviously it's hard to review a record that's made it to top ten rock lists just about everywhere, as well as being one of the best selling records of all time. That's a lot to live up to. In my honest opinion I can say that it ALMOST lives up to it's reputation. <br /> <br />Before I get into the individual songs (if you can call them individual) I'd like to say that in no way do I believe that this is Pink Floyd's best album. That title belongs to either \\"Piper at the Gates of Dawn\\" or \\"Wish You Were Here,\\" two starkly different but equally superb entries from Floyd. <br /> <br />The album starts off with \\"Breathe/Speak to Me,\\" a beautiful, atmospheric opener that perfectly sets the trippy tone that's going to pop up during the rest of the album. It's one of the best tracks on the album as well. It was just a very unique and brilliant move to make a collage of sounds that appear at various times during the album and put them in the beginning of this song. Of course you wouldn't know what it was until the second time you listen to the album, but it was a very artsy move, and a good one at that. It's starts the album off very well. <br /> <br />Some of the highlights are \\"Time,\\" \\"Money,\\" and \\"Brain Damage/Eclipse,\\" \\"Time\\" and \\"Money\\" being the heavy (and funky at times) rockers on the album. Both of them contain some relatively famous guitar solos and brilliant usage of sound effects throughout. Gilmour's either got some heavy fuzz, or twangy blues guitar and it really fits, or should I say he MAKES it fit. <br /> <br />\\"Brain Damage/Eclipse\\" is a triumphant sounding ending number that really ends the album on a high note. But that's where my complaints come in...that's it. With the exception of \\"Us and Them\\" (which is just entirely to slow for my liking) the rest is just filler. \\"On the Run\\" is just a 3 mintue long synth and drum loop. \\"The Great Gig in the Sky\\" sounds very over indulgent with the exaggerated screams of a soul singer pulling the entire  4  (almost5) mintue song. \\"Any Color You Like\\" is the most interesting of the three fillers with some heavy effect driven guitar solos popping up, but for the most part it's just another 3 minute synth workout. <br /> <br />In no way shape or form am I trying to convince anyone not to check this album out. In fact, I'm relatively sure any review is going to change a persons mind about this particular album. It's become so famous over the years that it's classic status has led some people to completely ignore it's problems in certain places. What I can tell you is that this is a very atmospheric, well devised record that definitely deserves attention, but when it comes to the fame it's recieved over the years, I can't say I think it lived up to it's reputation. But hey, one could argue that all the filler was created in order to sync up better with \\"The Wizard of Oz.\\" Who knows. I just know I like watching the movie more when the album is playing with it...
B0000039QA|5.0|As you're probably aware, the Notorious B.I.G.'s life was tragically cut short in March 1997, and his final album, the double-disc \\"Life After Death,\\" was released as scheduled mere weeks later. \\"Life After Death\\" is stunning in more ways than one. In a word, this album is epic. Over the course of two discs and 24 tracks, Biggie compiled a spectacle of a collection, with big-time productions, A-list collaborations, and hit singles. More so than his landbreaking debut [[ASIN:B0000039PW Ready to Die]], which was overall a grimier, humbler approach to a masterpiece, \\"Life After Death\\" is a big-budget, remarkable project to behold. Where his debut was filled with rags-to-riches tales of hustling and crime, the change his newfound wealth brought to his lifestyle is refelcted in his sophomore effort. The glamorous tales of his lavish lifestyle are highlighted in club tracks and party jams, but lyrically and technically he is as good here as he ever was. The spooky storytelling, hilarious punchlines, wide-eyed philosophy, and chilling threats are at their most effective. Technically, he is even better than before, utilizing an impeccable flow and vocabulary. Probably most stunning though, is the dramatic way in which he talks about death, given that he would die before this album would even be released. Whether referring to others or himself, his talk of the afterlife and judgement is among the most interesting and amazing parts this album has to offer. The tracklist is long and split between many types of tracks, including great radio-friendly singles, grimy street anthems, chilling narratives, seductive tracks for the ladies, and club songs. But somehow, he was able to pull all of these different intangibles together for another fluent masterpiece. Sean Combs and Easy Mo Bee anchor a production team that also includes such big names as Clark Kent, RZA, Kay Gee, Buckwild, and DJ Premier for production that lives up to the MC in every manner. \\"Life After Death\\" is another incredible hip hop album and much to behold.<br /><br />Following the intro, the first disc opens with \\"Somebody's Gotta Die,\\" a hard, grimy narrative with production and lyricism that will bring to mind multiple tracks from the debut. The light-hearted \\"Hypnotize\\" is an unforgettable single that remains in heavy radio rotation even today, a bass-heavy party jam with funny punchlines and a silly hook. DJ Premier produced \\"Kick in the Door,\\" a solid, upbeat track, and R. Kelly guests on the popular \\"F... You Tonight,\\" a seductive love song with great production. Fellow (then) Bad Boy artists The LOX collaborate for \\"Last Day,\\" a hard-hitting streets cut, and Jay-Z and Angela Winbush are the guests for the lavish anthem \\"I Love the Dough.\\" This song is a definite highlight, the production is rich, upbeat, and very funky, and the happy yet thoughtful song is lots of fun to listen to. \\"What's Beef?\\" assesses the state of rivalry both in hip hop and urban life, lyrically a strong piece. Biggie's most famous single comes next on the tracklist, \\"Mo Money Mo Problems,\\" a true anthem featuring Ma$e, Puff Daddy, and a sample from Diana Ross. This song is ingeniously produced, utilizing the sample brilliantly, and the joyful verses combined with great production equal a true musical triumph for the trio, the song that epitomized Bad Boy Records. The rough \\"N... Bleed\\" and the clever \\"I Got a Story to Tell,\\" the tale of a late-night escapade over a nice beat, close disc one.<br /><br />Disc two opens with a bang, the epic six-minute Bone Thugs-N-Harmony collaboration \\"Notorious Thugs.\\" This song is a true classic, with a phenomenal, Cleveland-styled beat and well-written, rapid-fire verses from the MCs. 112 provides the R&B hook and bridge for the sad \\"Miss U,\\" which flexes great production, and his young protege Lil Kim provides a memorable appearance on the funny \\"Another.\\" At this point, the classic joints come one after another. \\"Going Back to Cali\\" is an excellent, upbeatfunker with the luxurious tales of laidback life on the west coast. DJ Premier's masterful production on \\"Ten Crack Commandments\\" provides a backdrop for Biggie to drop wisdom from his days as a hustler. \\"Playa Hater\\" is the funniest song on the album, where Biggie sings like a silly soul singer, hilariously informing a victim, \\"You've been robbed.\\" The light and funky \\"Nasty Boy\\" precedes another dramatic 112 collaboration, which opens with words of motivation from none other than his mother. My favorite song on the whole album is \\"The World Is Filled...,\\" which features Too Short and Puff Daddy. This song doesn't stand out among the epic tracks here, but I've always found the laidback production and harsh philosophy relaxing. The last three songs are the most stunning, epic, and dramatic, dealing with death. \\"My Downfall\\" samples Run-DMC for a chilling chorus, a very well done and effective song. The infamous Wu-Tang beatcraft the RZA produced \\"Long Kiss Goodnight,\\" an eerie threat to a backstabber with an excellent chorus. Most chilling of all, though, is the closer \\"You're Nobody (Til Somebody Kills You).\\" This song is so chilling because the words he preached here proved so ironically true, very sadly. The beat is perfect and this song is absolutely chilling.<br /><br />\\"Life After Death\\" is dramatic and epic first and foremost, a phenomenal work that tragically was the last we will ever see of the great Christopher Wallace, one of the finest MCs to ever rock the mic. This album had such a wide influence, it's interesting for me to see how many of today's rappers are still recycling lines and beats from this album even ten years later. Unlike many listeners, I find this album at least every bit as fulfilling as his classic debut, and I recommend it to any hip hop fan.luxurious tales of laidback life on the west coast. DJ Premier's masterful production on \\"Ten Crack Commandments\\" provides a backdrop for Biggie to drop wisdom from his days as a hustler. \\"Playa Hater\\" is the funniest song on the album, where Biggie sings like a silly soul singer, hilariously informing a victim, \\"You've been robbed.\\" The light and funky \\"Nasty Boy\\" precedes another dramatic 112 collaboration, which opens with words of motivation from none other than his mother. My favorite song on the whole album is \\"The World Is Filled...,\\" which features Too Short and Puff Daddy. This song doesn't stand out among the epic tracks here, but I've always found the laidback production and harsh philosophy relaxing. The last three songs are the most stunning, epic, and dramatic, dealing with death. \\"My Downfall\\" samples Run-DMC for a chilling chorus, a very well done and effective song. The infamous Wu-Tang beatcraft the RZA produced \\"Long Kiss Goodnight,\\" an eerie threat to a backstabber with an excellent chorus. Most chilling of all, though, is the closer \\"You're Nobody (Til Somebody Kills You).\\" This song is so chilling because the words he preached here proved so ironically true, very sadly. The beat is perfect and this song is absolutely chilling.    \\"Life After Death\\" is dramatic and epic first and foremost, a phenomenal work that tragically was the last we will ever see of the great Christopher Wallace, one of the finest MCs to ever rock the mic. This album had such a wide influence, it's interesting for me to see how many of today's rappers are still recycling lines and beats from this album even ten years later. Unlike many listeners, I find this album at least every bit as fulfilling as his classic debut, and I recommend it to any hip hop fan.
B000058983|5.0|It's hard to understand why great albums are so often overlooked, but this album in particular is a hidden gem. Despite it's appearance on many top 100 (and even 10 on occasion) rock albums of all time, this one, for the most part, has been forgotten by the general public. It's a shame too, because it rightfully belongs on those top 100 and 10 lists. <br /> <br />Without going through every single song (they're all beautiful and still sound fresh to this day) some of the highlights of the album include \\"Alone Again Or\\" \\"Old Man\\" \\"Red Telephone\\" and \\"Live and Let Live.\\" They're all unique blends of folk-rock, psychedelia, baroque, jazz, and hard rock in some places. At no time does this album sound over indulgent or overblown. The strings, which often make songs sound very cheesy, fit in perfectly with Arthur Lee's (and Maclean's) beautiful compositions and the horns add a certain power as well. None of it ever sounds out of place or forced. There are unique key changes and unusual vocals throughout that just make this album sound unusually innovative and perpetually fresh. Even nearly 40 years after it's release, there are things that can be heard and learned from this album. \\"Live and Let Live,\\" which really sounds like the albums staple, is a brilliant folky pop gem that incorporates a lot of the properties listed above, as well as some electric guitar work that is fitted in perfectly to add that extra power in the middle of the song. <br /> <br />To tell the truth, it's really hard for me to recommend individual songs on this album, as they're all great. And you can't say that about many albums. It's quite easy to listen to it completely through without it ever sounding tedious or overly long. It's just that good. Do yourself a favor and buy this album. There's really nothing else to say.
B0000039PW|5.0|The Notorious B.I.G.'s 1994 debut arrived at a turning point for hip hop music. As the old school style from the east coast was slowly growing stale, a new funkier and angrier approach was steadily growing in the form of gangsta rap from the west coast. Then, of course, came \\"Ready to Die,\\" one of the finest hip hop albums of all time, and one that bridged the gap between the old and new schools. This is the album that introduced the world to the incredible rapper and incredible character that was Christopher Wallace. A young, overweight Brooklyn native, a father, and a former hustler, Biggie impressed listeners not only with his talent but his personality on the mic. Technically, he is not short of amazing. His ingenious punchlines, late-night stories, threats, and jokes are delivered in his raspy, cheeky voice with precise technique, always on time and in a perfect flow. Lyrically, he covers many topics but the quality is ever so consistent. On one song, he'll be telling a story of crime, on the next song he'll be poking fun at a ghetto loser, or seducing a woman, nostalgically reminiscing over the past, or dramatically philosophizing about the meaning of life and death. His verses are all meticulously written and never lose your attention. Another reason \\"Ready to Die\\" is so great is the production. The young Sean Combs anchors a production team that uses extensive, clever sampling to create a unique musical backdrop for Biggie. The album is well divided between radio friendly singles and harder, darker songs that would be too rough for radio. The hardcore tracks inspired an entire generation of grimy New York rappers that would reign towards the late 1990s, but the influence of the popular singles could also be felt on urban radio for years to come. \\"Ready to Die\\" is an absolutely classic hip hop album and one of the finest ever, a must have for any collection.<br /><br />The album begins with a dramatic intro, which gives way to \\"Things Done Changed,\\" a well-produced and ironic look back at Biggie's humble roots. \\"Gimme the Loot\\" is one of the songs that shows his lyrical genius, where he plays multiple characters in a conversation, creating a classic track. \\"Machine Gun Funk\\" is an upbeat, funky cut sampling a song by Lords of the Underground for the hook. On the excellent \\"Warning,\\" Biggie again plays multiple characters during conversation, before dropping philosophy on backstabbers and issuing threats. The title track follows accordingly, as does the original mix of \\"One More Chance,\\" a song to a woman about their relationship (the more popular remix is not included on the tracklist). Perhaps my favorite song is the Method Man collaboration \\"The What,\\" a song where the two depressed MCs drop some dark knowledge and philosophy over a great beat. It doesn't get much better than having two of New York's finest rappers over a solid 1994-styled beat. \\"Juicy\\" is an absolute classic, an emotional and effective rags-to-riches look at his upbringing, effectively sampling an 80s R&B hit by Mtume. Another of my favorites is the hopeful \\"Everyday Struggle,\\" which is blessed with the nicest beat on the album, a sunny, clever production over which Biggie recounts the troubles of trying to get by. \\"Me & My B...\\" is a humorous and enjoyable tune, followed by the unforgettable hit \\"Big Poppa.\\" This song has a perfect, Isley Brothers-sampling beat, a head-nodding funker, and shows the humorously seductive BIG at his finest. The well done \\"Respect\\" and catchy \\"Friend of Mine\\" are worthy deep-album cuts, and the DJ Premier-produced \\"Unbelievable\\" has an unforgettable chorus and production. The album closes with one of his most stunning works, \\"Suicidal Thoughts,\\" a depressing insight of life from a suicidal person.<br /><br />Overall, \\"Ready to Die\\" is inspiring, beautiful, and immensely entertaining. This album doesn't sound like it has aged a bit, and even thirteen yeras later sounds as fresh and incredible as the day it dropped. Listeners of any age should be able to appreciate this masterpiece, it's so consistent that there's not one piece of skip material over seventeen tracks. Unarguably one of the finest hip hop albums ever, I cannot recommend it any higher.e should be able to appreciate this masterpiece, it's so consistent that there's not one piece of skip material over seventeen tracks. Unarguably one of the finest hip hop albums ever, I cannot recommend it any higher.

B0007Y08QA|5.0|If you like your movies dark, depressing, eerie, mysterious, and borderline insane, The Machinist should definitely be on your \\"to see\\" list.  In these days of sequel- and remake-itis, it's always a treat to find a movie that dares to be original and to walk a dark line all its own.  Director Brad Anderson and Christian Bale definitely get an A+ for effort here, but I don't think the ending is quite as effective as it could have been.  It's easy to cross the line when you're dancing in a dark and narrow place, and the movie went just a little too far into \\"the whole world's crazy and everyone's out to get me\\" (which, on a completely unrelated point, is my personal motto) territory before bringing everything into focus.  (That doesn't stop me from giving the film five stars, however - The Machinist is worlds better than most of the junk coming out of Hollywood these days.)  Speaking of effort, I don't know what to say about Christian Bale - no Fat Albert to begin with - dropping 63 pounds in order to play the character of Trevor Reznik in this film.  He is painfully thin here; a few less pounds, and you could zoom him right through your copy machine and have all the Christian Bales you could want.  Why is his character so thin?  Well, he hasn't slept in a year, and that kind of wears on a fellow after a while.<br /><br />Trent is - you guessed it - a machinist.  It doesn't look like a great job, but he obviously makes a killing, as he leaves $20 tips every night at the diner and enjoys many an evening with a call girl who sort of becomes his girlfriend.  Jennifer Jason Leigh is about the only pretty thing you'll see in the 102 minutes of the film.  We first meet Trevor when he's approaching his breaking point.  The job of machinist can be quite hazardous, especially if you work with Trevor.  When a guy punches in with two arms and punches out with only one, the co-workers get a little restless.  Technically, it's Trevor's fault, but he was distracted by this seriously weird co-worker he had just recently met - a guy who, according to everyone else in the shop, doesn't even exist.  As you might expect, Trevor becomes rather obsessed about finding out who the guy is and what he wants.  As he goes increasingly cuckoo for cocoa puffs, his only links with sanity are Stevie (Jennifer Jason Leigh) the call girl and Marie (Aitana Sanchez-Gijon), his regular waitress at the airport caf&eacute;.<br /><br />The best way I can describe The Machinist is to suggest that it must be a lot like one of Tim Burton's dreams.  There's an oppressive pallor over the whole thing that seems to drain every single image of any color or vitality, and Trevor moves around rather wraith-like in his emaciated form.  The mystery of it all starts out with great strength, but I think the director just overplayed his hand a tiny bit - and, by doing so, made the ultimate ending somewhat (but not completely) predictable.  It's still a five-star effort all the way.  If you just want to forget the world and be entertained for an hour and a half, seek your pleasure elsewhere.  When you're ready to indulge the dark side of your personality and engage your mind at the same time, though, you could do much worse than settling yourself into a cocoon and entering the surreal world of The Machinist.  This film is, in a word, different.sly weird co-worker he had just recently met - a guy who, according to everyone else in the shop, doesn't even exist. B000002H33|4.0|That is a very good question.  I will attempt to answer it.  This is Metallica's third studio album complete with 8 songs and is tied with Ride the Lightning for their best album. This is also the last album with Cliff Burton (RIP), but I'm sure you have heard about that before you even clicked on this website.   This respectable bassist died when their tour bus got in an accident in Sweden.  His death may have been what lead to the demise of this great metal band.  I advise you do not listen to anything past the black album (even that is so-so). I also find the instrumental Orion to be a bit boring and that the instrumental The Call of Ktulu from Ride the Lightning to be far superior in comparison.   I'm sure there are a few other pointers I could give, but nothing comes to mind right now.      The fact is that this album is a classic in its own right.  But it is overrated at the same time.  I listen to this thing maybe once a month and within the same month I'll listen to Slayer's Reign in Blood and Seasons in the Abyss roughly 10 times.  The thing that Made Metallica famous were their Lyrics and Guitar work, yet with the days of St. Anguish, We shall never see that again.  So maybe now the other fact that the real Metallica is extinct, may make some treasure it even more, but at the same time it's also rather depressing, seeing a giant such as this, take such a mighty fall.  But looking back at this time capsule, we can escape to a place that will always be there, a place where Cliff is still alive, a place where we are locked in our homes (Sanitarium) and a place where there is still the threat of Global war (Disposable Heroes).  But even this classic is flawed or overrated.  Pick another word like perfect, mind blowing or even terrible for some and it shall be that in some way.  Should it be in your CD collection?  Yes.  Should it be one of your top favorites?  It's all up to your opinion and taste. 0671027344|5.0|I finished reading \\"The Perks of Being a Wallflower\\" over a month ago and still find myself haunted by it. This was definitely not the reaction I expected to a book published by MTV, but chances are \\"Wallflower\\" is the exception, not the rule. A lot of other reviews would argue that Charlie is incredibly pathetic and whiny, but I think they fail to understand that stems from his depression. The fact that he responds to the events in his life by either crying about it or drawing away from reality - such as going to the mall to figure out \\"why people go there\\" after relations with his best friends, Patrick and Sam, sour - explains the title and the moral of the story, which is that Charlie must stop being a \\"wallflower\\" and has to assert himself if he is to change his own life or the lives of others. <br /> <br />This really isn't another \\"young adult\\" novel, though the content doesn't delve too far past the difficulties of high school and the merits of The Smiths. However, I was skeptical how realistic it was that, within a few weeks of Charlie's entering high school, he became immersed in a world of drugs and sex that he was completely ignorant of before. I think a lot of books aimed at teenagers insist on offering that as an authentic teenage experience when, to be completely honest, there are plenty of young people who don't experiment with drugs or sex. Nonetheless, there are points when \\"Wallflower\\" hits the mark when it comes to a fifteen-year-old boy's sexual development. Charlie's discovery of masturbation would have to be one of my favorite scenes in the book.

B0000019PA|1.0|This album - and, I might add, virtually anything coming from the incestuous circle of much over-praised Elephant 6 bands - should be  right up the alley of any addled indie-rock nitwits who confuse \\"quirky\\" with \\"quality.\\" <br />It is filled with what otherwise would have been pleasantly bland, aimless songs that are only made somewhat interesting through overwrought arrangements of 'everything but the kitchen sink' instrumentation (and I'm not so sure a kitchen sink or two wasn't thrown in there somewhere). <br />And then there are those lyrics! Those dreadfully awful highschool poetry lyrics...  sheesh... \\"...Standing on the sea-weed water/Semen stains the mountain tops...\\" or \\"While powerful pistons were sugary sweet machines/Smelling of semen all under the garden\\" Oh lord, make it stop. <br />I figure this album should appeal greatly to pretentious and intellectually insecure teenagers who embrace anything they don't readily understand (assuming it has acquired the hipster stamp of approval) as mysterious and brilliant; when, in fact, it might be nothing more than nonsensical gibberish. <br />Okay, so where does that leave us? In fairness, this probably deserves 2, maybe even 3 stars -- there are far worse albums out there. I only gave it 1 (and would have given 0 if I could) as a reality check, in response to all the irrational praise heaped upon it. So give it a listen... judge for yourself... listen to the pretty horns... to the pretty saws... to Mangum's intriguing voice... <br />Try to ignore the inane lyrics... and the fact that you aren't being dazzled with brilliance, but rather baffled with- well, you know how the saying goes. <br />Sorry kids; your King of Carrots isn't wearing any clothes.

0451205766|5.0|I have had \\"The Godfather\\" on my shelf for about a year now but only just got around to reading it. I must say I was not prepared with the force with which Mario Puzo's storytelling leapt off the page and grabbed me. I have seen the film, of course - everyone should - but the book contains the details, sub-plots and first-person perspectives that no film can match. Puzo's narrative voice is cool but forceful, and full of dry irony. It's compulsively readable, I literally had to force myself to put it down!  Highly recommended. <br /> <br />However, I do want to warn readers away from the over-priced New American Library version - the trade paperback in a red foil cover with \\"The Original Classic\\" at the top. This edition is littered with typos, many of them errors that a simple spell-checking program would have caught. It's very distracting and annoying. Penguin should be ashamed to peddle such shoddy merchandise.  Get the mass-market paperback instead; the black cover is more sinister, anyway.

0441003257|4.0|I really hate that the cover of my book touted \\"Good Omens\\" as being on par with the superior \\"Hitchhiker's Guide\\" books (Douglas Adams) because those are treasures that will end up in the annals of classic literature some day. And while this is a great book, it does not hold a candle to Adams.<br /><br />I will say it again, though ... \\"Good Omens\\" is a great read. It captures a fine blend of seriousness and laugh-out-loud situations. There are so many great quirks, from a demon who has come to love the Earth a little too much, to prophet Agnes Nutter's offbeat (and mostly accurate) foretellings, you'll find yourself laughing a lot. And it has the best ending to ANY book I have EVER read. Hands down outstanding on the end.<br /><br />A few minor quibbles, such as a few mishandled characters and some muddling of the plot at times. It's nothing that should keep you from reading this book, however. If you like Science Fiction or Comedies, this is a wonderful mix of both genres.

B000001F3C|5.0|...to this album! As a young Kiwi I'd loved \\"I Will Follow\\" and \\"Gloria\\", but this album was a step beyond those early, determinedly modern forays. There is a lot more passion here - the political and spiritual awareness that later somehow transposed into the stale activism and preachy dreck of \\"Rattle & Hum\\" (thanks goodness they woke up and brought out ACHTUNG BABY). Although personally I rate THE UNFORGETTABLE FIRE a bit higher than this its not by much...there are so many magnificent songs here! My personal favourites are \\"New Years Day\\" and \\"Two Hearts\\" (great singles, cold and wintry), \\"Seconds\\" - the Edge sounds unsettlingly like Bono here, and the music is dark and menacing, \\"Drowning Man\\" a passionate, Celtic-inflected ballad and \\"Surrender\\" a searing, soaring piece of late night-urban angst that collapses into the gentle summer morning, the quiet optimism of grace that is \\"40\\". <br />Although they have done many good things (and some not-so-good) since, this album and its immediate successor remain, for me, the peak of their achievement. Perhaps its because the Cold War background and threat of nuclear apocalypse fitted so nicely into the band's Christian eschatology...or maybe I was just at the right age and this review is hopelessly nostalgic. Either way, check it out. Its good.
B000002G85|4.0|Eric Clapton is surrounded by a cornucopia of musicians and vocalist on this his first solo album. <br />Delaney and Bonnie Bramlett, Stephen Stills, Rita Coolidge, Bobby Whitlock, Jim Gordon, Carl Radle, Leon Russell and several more lend a hand or two, and Clapton has co-written about half of the album's eleven songs with Bonnie Bramlett, the half-decent instrumental \\"Slunky\\" and the fine blues-rock numbers \\"Bad Boy\\" and \\"Bottle Of Red Wine\\" among them. <br /> <br />There is perhaps a little less pop-rock and a little more blues-rock here than on most of Clapton's seventies solo albums, and many of the songs that were to become concert standarts throughout the decade came from this album: Clapton's rendition of J.J. Cale's \\"After Midnight\\", the sturdy rockers \\"Blues Power\\" and \\"Bottle Of Red Wine\\" and the grand \\"Let It Rain\\".  <br />Eric Clapton could have let loose a bit more when he recorded the vocals, and fans of his guitar hero persona may feel that he should have soloed a bit more and with a bit more reckless abandon, but this eponymous 37-minute album is nevertheless a nice, cohesive listen with plenty of highlights and precious few let-downs...a \\"cozy\\" album, and a sign of things to come as far as what Clapton's 70s solo career would bring. <br /> <br />\\"Eric Clapton\\" is not one of Clapton's better-known solo albums, but it has several good melodies and a lot of excellent musicanship, and while it doesn't reach the hights of \\"Layla\\" or \\"From The Cradle\\" it is definitely one of Clapton's better efforts.

B000003S1A|5.0|if you pick up this album, take the effort to totally step out of the sound and image of the band's legendary first album. this is not the court of the crimson king (and if that's the basis of your interest in this album, you're bound to be disappointed), but it is great music in its own right.    in contrast to the operatic prog bombast and moodiness of the first album, discipline is a totally different cup of tea inspired by images of africa and dominated by guitar wizard adrian belew fresh from his outings with talking heads/brian eno - the remarkable 'remain in light' - and heavily influenced by david bryne's vocal delivery, which itself is the exact opposite of the melancholy magnificence of greg lake's vocals in tcotck. fripp apparently wanted to call the band itself \\"discipline\\", but somehow the tag of \\"king crimson\\" was retained. soulful ballads interspersed with manic funk, layered with sinuous lead guitar duels, courtesy fripp and belew, characterises this album. bill bruford's \\"batterie\\", as subtle and powerful as ever, and tony levin's funky exploring bass, form the formidable rhythym section for the axemen to work on. fripp is still the brain behind the scenes, guiding and directing and his evolution as a musician/producer influenced by brain eno, is marked here. elephant talk, matte kudasai, the hilarious indiscipline, the sheltering sky are the highlights in this album. this album is as unique as it gets - never heard anything like this before or after!

B000067CPX|5.0|Yeah, OK, \\"maturing\\" is a bit of a dirty word - not one you might like to see associated with the Chilis, but I just can't think of a better one.  <br />Like many people, I was enraptured by the energy of the early Chilis - and perhaps like many others, I was a little disappointed with thier work after Mothers Milk. But not, I suspect, for the same reasons as many. <br />It wasn't that I felt the Chilis were selling out on cuts like \\"BloodSugarSexMagik\\" - I felt that they just weren't going far enough! Adolescent sexual energy is all very well, but after a while gets a little boring. I lost interest in this band that wasn't rekindled until I heard \\"Scar Tissue\\", which I felt showed increasing depth and adventure. I am glad (yes there is a point to all this preamble) to see that direction and energy maintained on \\"By The Way\\". The lyrics are not so goofy, in fact very acute. The musicianship is a lot more understated, which is great. i used to love hearing Frusciante's and Flea's virtuosity, but on this album they prove that understatement has as much - if not more - power than flash and glitter! And Anthony Kiedis' singing is constantly improving. <br />All the tracks are great, although the best for me are \\"This Is The Place\\" - a menacing piece where Kiedis basically rips his heart out and offers it warts and all for our perusal - \\"Don't Forget Me\\", where the menace gets even more menacing, with some of the darkest and broodiest poetry I've heard in a while, \\"Midnight\\" - great chorus - \\"Minor Thing\\", which simply soars at the end and the rousing, superb closer \\"Venice Queen\\", a lament that pulses with restrained energy and power. Restraint is the key word for this album. Sometimes less is more.

Harry was disciplined by his own department for his \\"cowboy\\" approach on the apprehension, but now he is standing trial in a civil suit by the surviving wife for use of excessive force. Not only is he facing tough female attorney \\"Money\\" Chandler, but a body, a \\"concrete blonde,\\" has just been found buried in concrete with the same MO used by the Dollmaker. Did Harry kill the wrong man?<br /><br />This story proceeds on two fronts: the courtroom and an intense LAPD investigation into the impossibility of a dead man committing another murder. From the court proceedings, Harry realizes that a Follower has been copying the Dollmaker even before the shooting. But only an insider could have exactly duplicated the Dollmaker's crime scenes. Harry must now proceed cautiously in not falsely targeting a fellow associate, yet quickly as it becomes clear that Follower will strike soon. The tale is gripping and well-constructed with any number of twists that fit well in the story line. Although I believe WAR to be a more coherent offering, the aura of experiment surrounding this cut is key to its strengths and weaknesses. <br />\\"A Sort of Homecoming\\" is a brilliant opener, with remarkable imagery in the lyrics, viz. <br /> <br />-The wind will crack <br />in winter time <br />this bomb blast lightning waltz <br />No spoken words, just a scream <br /> <br />or, <br /> <br />-See faces plowed like fields <br />that once gave no resistance <br /> <br />Wow - Bono certainly has his banal moments, but this is most definitely not one of them. The music is a summery haze of guitars (Eno is clearly evident here) and the vocal delivery passionate and sincere. <br />The next track \\"Pride (In the Name of Love)\\" is actually my least favourite on the album - although I think it rather good anyway, and, as it is very well-known, I'll move on. \\"Wire\\" the next track is simply the nastiest and most vicious piece U2 have ever done. It is, I understand, about addiction, and, with its dark imagery, odd, disconnected vocal lines and very chthonic rhythm, it is the best - in aesthetic terms - the best song they've done. <br />\\"The Unforgettable Fire\\" is a great song too, with Bono reaching new heights as a vocalist on the bridge (although check out his collaboration with Clannad, \\"In A Lifetime\\", recorded around this time). \\"Promenade\\" is nice, cathartic and light after the violence and power of what has come before, and the summer ennui of that piece carries over into \\"4th July\\" and the beginning of \\"Bad\\" - a song that is the precursor to U2's stadium/epic identity, but for all that, not too shabby. <br />\\"Indian Summer Sky\\" is OK, like \\"Wire\\" but without the malevolence and self-loathing that drive that song. \\"Elvis Presley & America\\" I really love - its a sloppy, meandering piece with incomprehensible vocals, but its half-finished feel is what gives it its charm. <br />\\"MLK\\" is apiece of beauty: a lullaby atop Eno's lush keyboards, a truly gentle way to end an album dedicated to the spirit of exploration and growth...this CD is a piece of flawed magic.
0312323859|5.0|After reading Something Borrowed I really could not have imagined feeling badly for Darcy.  Griffin really does a good job of showing you Darcy in a different light.  It was a quick and enjoyable read, a great follow up!
B000A2GS54|4.0|Well, it's about time Manchester got a revival -- it's been around fifteen years since bands like the Happy Mondays and Stone Roses erupted onto the music scene. Now with late-70s and mid-80s music being revived in newer, trendier bands, it's about time we got to England in the late-80s and mid-90s.<br /><br />Enter Kasabian, a Leicester band who put out catchy, synthy, and extremely entertaining rock'n'roll. What does their self-titled album sound like? Well, it has some echoes of those Manchester greats, except that it has a synth edge over those heavy riffs. Add in some very radio-friendly melodies, which are almost guaranteed to get these guys noticed by the media.<br /><br />Not that that's a bad thing -- they resemble fellow electro-Manchester band South, which happens to be among my favorite Britpop bands. Kasabian is just lighter. They kick things off on a strong note with the expansive \\"Clubb Foot,\\" which pairs gritty rock with sweeping synth, over Tom Meighan's languid vocals.<br /><br />Fortunately this is not one of those albums that has one good single, and then gets lazy. Things stay catchy and gritty, all throughout the album, with heavy riffs and steady rhythms, and Kasabian keep their style varied enough that listeners won't be left thinking, \\"Oh man, are they playing that riff AGAIN?\\"<br /><br />Not to mention the singing: Meighan has a very strong, melodious voice. In almost every song, he sings slow and lazily. He sounds either stoned or inattentive, except for a few wonderful songs where he sounds completely into what he sings. \\"John was a scientist, he was hooked on LSD/Interested in mind control and how the monkey held the key/Said that all life is experiments somebody's planning for the heir/It's for the unexpected citizens who hallucinate in fear,\\" he purrs happily.<br /><br />Yeah, it can get pretty heavy. but the music is also tempered with an ethereal edge -- there's a brief interlude which is all muffled riffs, deep synth and angelic vocals. At the very least, all that synth serves to lighten up what could have been a dark album, and adds an epic edge to what could have been terribly ordinary music.<br /><br />The flaw? It gets a bit fragmented, with two peppy electronic \\"interludes\\" sitting between harder rock'n'roll. They're pretty, but they feel out of place.<br /><br />Things climax with hints of another possible direction for them to go in: \\"U Boat,\\" a rich soundscape that fades away into silence... before fading back into a different mix of \\"Reason is Treason.\\" It's all hard angles and explosions, and if anything, this mix is even better than the radio-friendly original. (Talk about having your cake and eating it too)<br /><br />One of the few albums that is catchy and musically rich, Kasabian's debut is one of the best releases this year. It's reminiscent of Britpop greats, but somehow that doesn't matter -- they're original enough to have their own fun sound.ynth and angelic vocals. At the very least, all that synth serves to lighten up what could have been a dark album, and adds an epic edge to what could have been terribly ordinary music.  <br />  <br />The flaw? It gets a bit fragmented, with two peppy electronic \\"interludes\\" sitting between harder rock'n'roll. They're pretty, but they feel out of place.  <br />  <br />Things climax with hints of another possible direction for them to go in: \\"U Boat,\\" a rich soundscape that fades away into silence... before fading back into a different mix of \\"Reason is Treason.\\" It's all hard angles and explosions, and if anything, this mix is even better than the radio-friendly original. (Talk about having your cake and eating it too)  <br />  <br />One of the few albums that is catchy and musically rich, Kasabian's debut is one of the best releases this year. It's reminiscent of Britpop greats, but somehow that doesn't matter -- they're original enough to have their own fun sound.

B000000OAN|5.0|While progressive rockers may have been the first to provide significant injections of bombast into rock music, Queen raised bombast to a fine art, and created one of the greatest rock albums in the process of doing so.  Though there is bombast, there is beauty too, and Queen proved that a rock album could incorporate a huge diversity of styles and be successful.  This album is a critical component of any rock music collection.<br /><br />The album opens with the first of three rockers, \\"Death on Two Legs.\\"  This song has excellent metal poetry that eschews mumbled and garbled lyrics for clarity and evocation.  The words contain gems from beginning to end, such as the line \\"you're a sewer-rate decaying in a cesspool of pride.\\"  Guitars scream and wail and Queen's harmonies are sprinkled liberally throughout.  Yet this song retains an element of fun and retains a twinkle in its musical eye.  The other heavy rocker is an ode to muscle cars.  \\"I'm in Love with My Car\\" is a perfect cruising song with crunchy guitars and Roger Taylor's roaring vocal.  The two songs are different, but anchor one end of Queen's musical range.  Also included is a 1991 remix of this song.  There are a few differences between the songs, but I think I still prefer the original.  The third rocker is \\"Sweet Lady.\\"  This third song is loud and fast paced, but seems less inspired than much of the music on this album.<br /><br />After \\"Death on Two Legs\\" is the first of three songs that are quirky, fun and kind of clear the aural palate between songs.  \\"Lazing on a Sunday Afternoon\\" is an ode to the era of flappers and speakeasies.  \\"Seaside Rendezvous\\" is in a similar vein, and also comes after a rocker.  Roger Taylor and Freddie Mercury both do vocal interpretations of instruments that are remarkably effective and fun.  The third song in this vein is \\"Good Company,\\" which comes after \\"Love of My Life.\\"  This song has lead vocals by Brian May, along with a ukulele.  This song has a musical style more similar to songs of the 1930s, though with sufficient electronic effects to remind you that the song is influenced by that era but could only have been made in this era.  For reasons I am unable to explain this song is a perfect lead-in to \\"Bohemian Rhapsody.\\"<br /><br />\\"You're My Best Friend\\" and \\"Love of My Life\\" are two love ballads that show yet another capability of Queen.  \\"You're My Best Friend\\" was released as a single backed by the interesting song \\"'39\\" and reached #16 on the pop singles chart.  Freddie Mercury's vocals provide the emotional kick for this song, and make this song one of Queen's best.  \\"Love of My Life\\" falls into a similar vein, and features Brian May playing the harp.  This song is also beautiful and emotional, and in many ways is more powerful than \\"Love of My Life.\\"  In retrospect, I think this song could have been released as a single and would have done well.  This version of the CD includes a 1991 remix of \\"You're My Best Friend.\\"  I am unable to discern any significant difference between the two versions, and thus the addition is of minimal value.<br /><br />There is one song that is hard to categorize.  \\"God Save the Queen\\" is Brian May's interpretation of the English anthem.  Guitars predominate in this brief piece that somehow is a thank you to the Queen and country.<br /><br />Though the remaining three songs are quite different from each other, they share a commonality in that they are among the more experimental tracks on this CD, and being a fan of progressive rock, I think they are among the best tracks on this CD.<br /><br />The first of these songs is \\"'39.\\"  I have seen many interpretations of this song that combines a flavor of country-rock with several other styles to make a totally unique song.  I saw one review compare the style to Paul McCartney, and I see the relationship.  I could also see a comparison to the Eagle's Joe Walsh years.  The harmonies also remind me just a little of the Moody Blues.<br /><br />The next song in this category is \\"The Prophet's Song,\\" an 8:21 progressive rock masterpiece.  Brian May uses a toy koto, an unusual instrument that lends a slight Asian flavor to the introduction.  This song also features an a capella vocal by Freddie Mercury that is fascinating and adds to the numerous dimensions of this song that features a rocking end.<br /><br />The third song is the bombastic art rock classic \\"Bohemian Rhapsody.\\"  This phenomenal song can be treated as a parody of glam rock, or it can be considered in the context of a rock group that was unafraid of performing their art as they saw fit.  The pseudo operatic elements are wonderful and occasionally eerie and always fascinating.  The harmonies are outstanding and wonderfully excessive.  If ever a song captured everything good about rock music, this one is it.  This song charted the first time in 1976 and reached #9.  The second time the song charted was in 1992, when it reached #2.  You will have some kind of feeling about this song regardless of whether that reaction is one of awe or distaste, but those us who are fans of Queen and progressive rock usually love this one.<br /><br />Queen hit pay dirt with this album, which reached #4 on the Pop Albums chart.  This album was easily Queen's best album, showcasing the talents of four individuals who were able to able to come together and stay together until Freddie Mercury passed away.  While Queen had many excellent songs, they had at least one great album, and this was it.br /> <br />The next song in this category is \\"The Prophet's Song,\\" an 8:21 progressive rock masterpiece.  Brian May uses a toy koto, an unusual instrument that lends a slight Asian flavor to the introduction.  This song also features an a capella vocal by Freddie Mercury that is fascinating and adds to the numerous dimensions of this song that features a rocking end. <br /> <br />The third song is the bombastic art rock classic \\"Bohemian Rhapsody.\\"  This phenomenal song can be treated as a parody of glam rock, or it can be considered in the context of a rock group that was unafraid of performing their art as they saw fit.  The pseudo operatic elements are wonderful and occasionally eerie and always fascinating.  The harmonies are outstanding and wonderfully excessive.  If ever a song captured everything good about rock music, this one is it.  This song charted the first time in 1976 and reached #9.  The second time the song charted was in 1992, when it reached #2.  You will have some kind of feeling about this song regardless of whether that reaction is one of awe or distaste, but those us who are fans of Queen and progressive rock usually love this one. <br /> <br />Queen hit pay dirt with this album, which reached #4 on the Pop Albums chart.  This album was easily Queen's best album, showcasing the talents of four individuals who were able to able to come together and stay together until Freddie Mercury passed away.  While Queen had many excellent songs, they had at least one great album, and this was it. <br />

B000002AP1|5.0|When this album was released, the Stooges had spent the better part of 5 years alienating themselves from their record labels and mainstream audiences, and it barely made a blip on the album charts. Fortunately, posterity doesn't care about the vicissitudes of the people involved, only the output. And What output indeed...<br />Despite anemic sales figures, this album was immediately immortalized by critics, and it's easy to see why. I mean, MY GOD!!! All of the songs are strong-there's no indication that this band is near death-and the performances are transcendant. Despite two faulty mixes (David Bowie's muddled original mix and Iggy's overloaded effort present on this CD), this is one of the roughest, toughest, maddest, baddest releases EVER released by ANY band. It is impossible to express just how high my estimation of this album is, but let me assure you that after 8 years it remains the ultimate go-to rock disc in my sizable rock collection, and the CD case has the wear and tear to prove it.<br />If Rock is what you seek; if you are tired of \\"best of genre\\" album choices that leave you flat; if you seek high-energy rock of the first order; if you want to figure out just what the hype surrounding the Stooges was all about, GET THIS ALBUM NOW! You will not regret it.

B0009HLDFU|5.0|First off, this is a great double disc.  The main reason I am posting a review is that I heard there were issues with getting these copyrighted discs on iPods.  I have them on my iPod and here are directions on how to get it on yours...  Put the disc in CD-ROM and accept all licensing agreements.  Click on Copy Songs. Click on Select All Songs.  After it has copied all songs click on Continue.  Put under My Documents.  X out of screen after done with these steps.  Go to My Computer, My Documents, In_Your_Honor.  Highlight all songs, right click and click on Copy to CD or Device.  This will place all songs in the Window Media Player.  Burn a disc from the W.M.P. by placing your CD-R into the E: drive (this will convert all files from WMAs to MPEG-4s) Use burned disc to put songs on iPod and enjoy this great CD on your iPod as well now.

B00006AW2G|5.0|This very well could have been their best album. Here we have classics Gimme Shelter, Let It Bleed, Midnight Rambler and You Can't Always Get What You Want paired with Love In Vain, Live With Me, You Got the Silver and Monkey Man. The best songs are, in this order, Let It Bleed, Live With Me and Monkey Man. Eight of these tunes are truly great.<br /><br />But what about the ninth? Country Honk is such an unbelievable disgrace it's unspeakable. For those who haven't heard it (Oh ye lucky ones!) it's basically a countryfied take of Honky Tonk Women. The lyrics of the two songs are virtually the same, but while Honky Tonk Women is a blues-rock tune with saxes, Country Honk is a drunk Country tune with a fiddle. Had Honky Tonk Women been included instead of Country Honk, Let It Bleed would've been their greatest album. With Country Honk, it falls into third place behind Exile and Sticky Fingers. Regardless, I'd buy it if I were you.

Neverless, it's a classic mosher, and one of Testament's best songs w/ a great solo. <br /> <br />Track 2 : \\"Perilous Nation\\" - One of Bay Area thrashers finest numbers, w/ one of Skolnick's very best solos. Flawlessly written and executed; the highlight of the album. <br /> <br />Track 3 : \\"Envy Life\\" - Filler track w/ decent riffs. <br /> <br />Track 4 : \\"Time Is Coming\\" - Testament regains momentum on this track w/ great riffs and tempo changes, while leading into one of the album's best cuts. <br /> <br />Track 5 : \\"Blessed in Contempt\\" - The 2nd quickest song on the album , with driving riffs and a fantastic solo section, one of the album's best. <br /> <br />Track 6 : \\"Greenhouse Effect\\" -  One Testament's most popular songs is also one of their most lyrically accomplished, but not one of my personal favorites. <br /> <br />Track 7 : \\"Sins Of Omission\\" - Filler track w/ decent riffs. <br /> <br />Track 8 : \\"The Ballad\\" - Testament KNOWS ballads, and this is no exception. Opens with a sorta Pink Floyd type sound and transforms into thrash on a dime. One of Testament's best songs. <br /> <br />Track 9 : \\"Nightmare (Coming Back To You) - The quickest song on the album starts out feeling like as a filler track, but turns out to be a pretty infectious cut w/ a great solo. <br /> <br />Track 10: \\"Confusion Fusion\\" - Pointless, but fairly engaging  instrumental closer that could have been much more. <br /> <br />OVERALL: A very solid effort from one of the very best thrash bands ever, much better than \\"Souls Of Black\\" and \\"The Ritual\\".  \\"Perilous Nation\\" alone is worth the purchase price. <br /> <br />ALSO CHECK OUT: \\"The Legacy\\" and \\"The New Order\\" by Testament.

B000001DQI|5.0|As good as a large number of his albums are, Elton John is generally renowned more for his classic singles and individual songs, his celebrated partnership with lyricist Bernie Taupin having spawned some of the most memorable hits of the late 20th Century. However, \\"Captain Fantastic and The Brown Dirt Cowboy\\" was the first album ever to enter the US album chart at number one, while the debut at number one of it's follow-up, \\"Rock of The Westies\\" secured Elton as the first act to achieve back-to-back album releases to top of the American chart in the first week of release, not to mention the fact his 1974 \\"Greatest Hits\\" package remains one of the world's 20 best-selling albums of all time. For all these achievements though, I feel I can say only one Elton John album is a true \\"classic\\" - his 1973 double album, \\"Goodbye Yellow Brick Road\\".<br /><br />Although this is considered something of a concept album with the familiar strand it maintains throughout, I'm not quite sure where the album is supposed to lead to, if indeed it is meant to lead anywhere. It seems to surround Bernie Taupin's fascination with the American west, perhaps during the time of the depression in the 1930's, mixed with the apparent glamour of the Hollywood movies and some good old rock `n' roll from the 1950's.<br /><br />The album kicks off with the grand opening of \\"Funeral For A Friend / Love Lies Bleeding\\" which is the perfect epic start to a rock double album. From there, there are many music genres to be found, including the country honk of \\"Social Disease\\" and the reggae tinted \\"Jamaica Jerk Off\\", a song which Elton later admitted to hating. Elton's brilliant piano playing is particularly evident in songs like \\"Grey Seal\\" and the classic \\"Bennie And The Jets\\", a glam rock anthem if ever there was. Then of course there's \\"Candle In The Wind\\", arguably Elton and Bernie's most famous song but curiously just missing out on the Top 10 when originally released as a single in the UK. A live version reached number 5 in the UK in 1988, and, when rerecorded with lyrics rewritten in tribute to the late Diana, Princess of Wales, the song became the world's biggest selling single under the title of \\"Candle In The Wind 1997\\". Some of Elton's finest rock songs are found on this album - the eternal crowd-pleaser, \\"Saturday Night's Alright For Fighting\\", \\"Your Sister Can't Twist (But She Can Rock `N' Roll)\\", \\"All The Girls Love Alice\\" and \\"Dirty Little Girl\\". The ballads are just as memorable, from the whimsical title track to the melancholy \\"Sweet Painted Lady\\". Overall the album oozes confidence from Elton and his band at a time when he was riding the crest of his newfound success.<br /><br />Elton has said that he recorded this double album in an attempt to singularly fulfill the contractual obligation he had to his record company to record and release two albums per year (the record company didn't see it that way and still insisted on another record).  However, it's always seemed like commercial suicide for an artist to release a double album (hence why so few or probably even none are attempted nowadays) as so very few have been both good and successful (the Beatles' \\"White Album\\" and U2's \\"Rattle And Hum\\" being the only exceptions that spring to mind), but Elton managed to pull it off in brilliant style, not only recording a good double album but, in my opinion, still the best album of his career.e version reached number 5 in the UK in 1988, and, when rerecorded with lyrics rewritten in tribute to the late Diana, Princess of Wales, the song became the world's biggest selling single under the title of \\"Candle In The Wind 1997\\". Some of Elton's finest rock songs are found on this album - the eternal crowd-pleaser, \\"Saturday Night's Alright For Fighting\\", \\"Your Sister Can't Twist (But She Can Rock `N' Roll)\\", \\"All The Girls Love Alice\\" and \\"Dirty Little Girl\\". The ballads are just as memorable, from the whimsical title track to the melancholy \\"Sweet Painted Lady\\". Overall the album oozes confidence from Elton and his band at a time when he was riding the crest of his newfound success. <br /> <br />Elton has said that he recorded this double album in an attempt to singularly fulfill the contractual obligation he had to his record company to record and release two albums per year (the record company didn't see it that way and still insisted on another record).  However, it's always seemed like commercial suicide for an artist to release a double album (hence why so few or probably even none are attempted nowadays) as so very few have been both good and successful (the Beatles' \\"White Album\\" and U2's \\"Rattle And Hum\\" being the only exceptions that spring to mind), but Elton managed to pull it off in brilliant style, not only recording a good double album but, in my opinion, still the best album of his career. <br />

B00097DX3U|3.0|Rage Against the Machine and Soundgarden were outstanding (although I'll admit to a major bias in favor of Soundgarden), but I don't think the elements blend well together. It sounds like the guys from Rage are still writing songs for Zack De La Rocha rather than Chris Cornell. So, Chris Cornell is writing lyrics for music that really just sounds like Rage, and I don't think it works. They have a predictable pattern within their song structures, and once you notice it you'll want to stop listening. Rage was becoming repetitive before Zack left, and they haven't developed much more with Chris Cornell as a vocalist. They don't have the musical abilities to match the potential of Chris Cornell's voice. I love Soundgarden and Rage Against the Machine, but if this a new band, they should work out some different sounds. The drumming is boring and I'm over Tom M's guitar noodling. Even so, it's better than at least 50% of the new music out there so I can't justify anything less than 3 stars. I'll reserve the 1 and 2 star ratings for really horrible bands.
